author: shenron
title: Very much needed in a town
review:
In its own way, this is quite an essential set to build a decently sized town. But for some reasons, it was reissued only once, and I haven't seen a road sign accessory box for nearly 20 years.

All of the signs are printed (no stickers) are most are not available in other sets. 

With 12 signs (two of which in two copies), the size of this box is well chosen, considering that most young Legoland fans don't probably have more than a dozen roadplates, and 1-2 signs per roadplate is a good average.

There certainly could be many more signs than those included, and a notable miss here is the men-at-work sign, which in my opinion could have had a more common use than the "no-turn-left" sign.

author: CamberbrickGreen
title: Accident Prevention
review:
These road signs were great. The one piece design was a helpful 'filler' brick but nevertheless effective though I bet the stickers were hard to do with little fingers if application was needed.

Occupational Hazard
Sadly these thin pieces got absolutely trashed by us and became a haphazard of vandalised safety information and so accidents continued to happen and the emergency services remained employed.

The build is well,...rather obvious!

One of the speed limits reads '40'. Surely we got most vehicles past 100? Mechanic on stand by.

The recent town people set came with these and they were excellent with traffic lights too. The trouble is, once you have a few, you need a load more for the whole town to look right. building your own is pretty simple and fun with some spare bricks.

Warning: MFs get confused, misplacing signs can cause chaos.

SET REQUEST:
Beacons, Traffic Lights, Road Signs & Street Names.

author: Eric_Botswana
title: Sign of the times
review:
A supplementary set, sure, but a good one that really spruced up your roads. They were more for decoration than anything, I don't recall any of my Lego drivers paying any attention to them.

The downside for me though was I was an Australian child and several of these signs just aren't used in Australia. I had no idea what the blue one with the red diagonal line was supposed to mean. Smurfs not allowed?

Also many of these signs didn't last and were broken in the box.

Overall, a must to make your Lego town look more towny. Just don't expect drivers to obey them.

author: Niki124
title: So pleased with this set
review: As a small child I was obsessed with road signs, after reading about them in my Dad's road atlas. So, to have this set in our Lego collection was an achievement, even though we only had two road baseplates and both of those had buildings across them. I would have liked a greater variety of signs at the time, but nevertheless this was a welcome supplementary set.
